subs.text: July 30

@ReceiptsIn @ChrisO_wiki @mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed An outside observer might think that a nation which won its own independence partially due to ‘unconventional’ (for the time) and ‘uncouth’ guerrilla warfare …

… might have had at least ~some~ insight into the impracticality of a long-term occupation of determined populations.
subs.rawText:
@ReceiptsIn @ChrisO_wiki @mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed An outside observer might think that a nation which won its own independence partially due to ‘unconventional’ (for the time) and ‘uncouth’ guerrilla warfare …

subs.text:
@ChrisO_wiki @mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed Modern aircraft carriers are sitting ducks for both torpedoes and guided missiles.

They don’t (can’t) sail anywhere contested without ~multiple~ rings of protection (warships, electronic, and aviation), ranging out many ~hundreds~ of nautical miles.
subs.rawText:
@ChrisO_wiki @mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed Modern aircraft carriers are sitting ducks for both torpedoes and guided missiles.

They don’t (can’t) sail anywhere contested without ~multiple~ rings of protection (warships, electronic, and aviation), ranging out many ~hundreds~ of nautical miles.

subs.text:

“Hypersonic missiles and railguns may be fast, but they’re not faster than Motorola™”

subs.text:
@mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed @ChrisO_wiki The first military ‘mines’ were not explosives but rather 

… timber-braced tunnels dug underneath stone fortifications, such as castle walls. 

 (think old-time manual labor coal or silver mine tunnels, with pick-axes and little wooden carts)

1/4
subs.rawText:
@mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed @ChrisO_wiki The first military ‘mines’ were not explosives but rather 

… timber-braced tunnels dug underneath stone fortifications, such as castle walls. 

 (think old-time manual labor coal or silver mine tunnels, with pick-axes and little wooden carts)

1/4

subs.text:
@mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed @ChrisO_wiki Once complete, the wood inside was set on fire, and a few hours/days later the tunnels collapse and undermine the stone walls.

~ ~ ~ ~

Modern naval torpedoes work the same way; they are often set to explode ~beneath~ the keel of a large ship, not hit the ship directly.

2/4
subs.rawText:
@mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed @ChrisO_wiki Once complete, the wood inside was set on fire, and a few hours/days later the tunnels collapse and undermine the stone walls.

~ ~ ~ ~

Modern naval torpedoes work the same way; they are often set to explode ~beneath~ the keel of a large ship, not hit the ship directly.

2/4

subs.text:
@mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed @ChrisO_wiki The resulting shock wave rocks the ship and causes some damage… 

 … but the real fun starts when the pressure dissipates ~but before the water can rush back in~. 

(Spoiler: gas is compressible, water effectively isn’t, and ships are ~very~ heavy)

3/4
subs.rawText:
@mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed @ChrisO_wiki The resulting shock wave rocks the ship and causes some damage…

subs.text:
@mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed @ChrisO_wiki Basically, there’s nothing supporting the center of the ship anymore (aka a nautical sinkhole), and hopefully the now-damaged keel cracks from the uneven support.

~ ~ ~ ~

I imagine bridge piers don’t like their foundations to suddenly ‘blink out of existence’ either.

4/4

subs.text:
@stefan_meyer98 @zahed @gardenrichard There are a lot of ways to use it for low volume traffic (far under design loads) in good weather.

Even if damaged much further, it could still serve as a useful foundation / formwork for a temporary bridge (once Ukraine again has control of the area and isn’t under fire).

@zahed @ulrichwi @HeinzDieterDetl Probably also depends to what extent the Soviets over-engineered their bridges, right?

(i.e. If they were extra-conservative with safety margins and careful in construction, it may hold up better than some of the ramshackle post-war construction in North America.)

subs.text:
@jeputz @sleepingdingo @marktavern @natecochrane @EpsonAmerica Brother is one of the better ones in this regard.

(Also, regardless of brand, it is best to avoid upgrading the firmware of cheap printers unless you’re trying to resolve a specific issue or are promised a specific new feature that is of value to you.)

subs.text:
@DrKittensaurus @margaritaloxas Consider a stable patient that could justifiably be discharged from a hospital in the evening vs. the next morning.

The knowledge that 12 extra, unnecessary, hours as an inpatient might cost them hundreds or thousands of extra dollars probably ~should~ factor into that decision.
subs.rawText:

subs.text:
@DrKittensaurus @margaritaloxas Okay, I think y’all actually agree on most of this, then.

If ~you~ can know that MRIs are expensive, and therefore only order them judiciously… and also are cognizant of that, so you aren’t overly biased to avoid them… 

… then we should teach all three of those, eh?

1/2

subs.text:
@DrKittensaurus @margaritaloxas Perhaps those resulting inequalities will be what it takes to rethink and reform health care funding?

If most people don’t realize the scale of the problem until _their own_ family falls into medical debt, then most people won’t prioritize working/voting to fix the root causes.

subs.text:
@SolitudinarianA @Misty_Melanie It’s hard not to ‘miss intent’ when that intent conflicts with logic (e.g. consistency with past statements), and the plain meaning of language.

Communication is a two-way street, and any failed communication (even if one party is ‘neuro-atypical’) indicates both sides can grow.

subs.text:
@Dennis_Ramen @FemiYahtzee It is:

1. hard (logistically speaking, to do at scale - i.e. each district needs to decide to take action, then decide what action to take, then hire/manage contractors)

2. unlike post-9/11 security, not backed by lobbyists and high-margin consultants

See also: infrastructure

subs.text:
@ReflectiveKen @AuthorConfusion @jonsteingard I thought the (fictional) description was more akin to a blender or a parallel-to-serial encoder;

i.e. the matter isn’t converted to energy, but rather sent in a very tight stream (as subatomic or perhaps quantum particles?) and then reassembled (much as a 3d printer does).
subs.rawText:
@ReflectiveKen @AuthorConfusion @jonsteingard I thought the (fictional) description was more akin to a blender or a parallel-to-serial encoder;

subs.text:
@ReflectiveKen @AuthorConfusion @jonsteingard (tight enough to pass through the mostly empty space in otherwise ‘solid’ walls, etc.)

If it was purely an energy-based copy, you could always reassemble the new version (and verify accuracy) before destroying the old - killing nearly all plots involving transporter ‘accidents’!

  Make new friends.
    Ask if they are registered to vote; if not, offer to help them to find out how to register or request mail/#absentee ballots.

  Election day should be a party!

subs.text: @Lift_Our_Voice #SocialProof “Japan in the Covid-19 pandemic, where they looked at the willingness … to wear a mask, and they looked at a variety of possible reasons: … The only one that made any difference was the number of people they saw wearing masks.” [link]
subs.rawText:
@Lift_Our_Voice #SocialProof

“Japan in the Covid-19 pandemic, where they looked at the willingness … to wear a mask, and they looked at a variety of possible reasons: …  

The only one that made any difference was the number of people they saw wearing masks.”

https://t.co/HT4K6OBr04

subs.text: July 1

‘The missions into Russia are “not a big secret,” said Shaman. “Sometimes it happens on a helicopter. Sometimes we go in by foot. Most of the times we’re able to locate the good entry point to fly in or to walk on foot into Russia and then afterwards, what can I say?”’ [link]
